text:
I'm working on a library for incremental computation that can handle loops/fixpoints/recursion, supports out-of-order inputs, will soon support automatic parallelization and whose api is focused on being a good backend for a language.

There's still a fair bit of work to go before it's useful, but there's enough working already to be worth reading - <https://github.com/jamii/dida>

attachments.title: jamii/dida
attachments.text: Differential dataflow for mere mortals. Contribute to jamii/dida development by creating an account on GitHub.

text:
Reading through this all I was thinking "aw this seems so cool, sad that I won't be able to use it because I'm entirely JS-based" and then at the bottom, you have WASM and Node listed as potential targets!

Um... godspeed!

text: Your commitment to documentation is commendable. The explanations are clear and simple, and the comments make the code itself easy to get acquainted with. Thank you!

elements.text: Your commitment to documentation is commendable. The explanations are clear and simple, and the comments make the code itself easy to get acquainted with. Thank you!

text: The node.js bindings should already work, although I haven't figured out yet how to package and ship them.

elements.text: The node.js bindings should already work, although I haven't figured out yet how to package and ship them.

text: Great stuff! I'm very interested in this work, as I'm building a node-based language that requires incrementalization to function at performance.

elements.text: Great stuff! I'm very interested in this work, as I'm building a node-based language that requires incrementalization to function at performance.

text: And happily it also uses something like tables as a base type!

text: May I respectfully request that you add `margin-left:2em;` to the CSS rule for `main`? I have just done so by hand to make it more pleasant to read the body copy.

elements.text: May I respectfully request that you add
margin-left:2em;
to the CSS rule for
main
? I have just done so by hand to make it more pleasant to read the body copy.

text: Done! Just so I understand, would reducing the width of `#page` also have had the same effect?

elements.text: Done! Just so I understand, would reducing the width of
#page
also have had the same effect?

text: :pray::skin-tone-2: The text shouldn't be flush to the left margin, it makes it harder to read because the eye fights the edge. Also, if you're designing for readability, the body copy should average between 12-14 words wide on each line. Wikipedia's default style sheet has long violated this latter norm, which makes it more difficult to read articles without an alternate stylesheet.

elements.text: The text shouldn't be flush to the left margin, it makes it harder to read because the eye fights the edge. (I also enjoyed the content, btw

text:
Ah, I see. I'm privileged to keep my windows wide enough that it doesn't go flush with the left margin.

As an experiment I just reduced the width of my website. In the past I found pages like <http://paulgraham.com/essay.html> too narrow, but now my site is the same width, and neither seems off. I'll keep this for a while and see how it feels.

More comments most welcome!

text: PG's essay has a width of 8-10, which is -- as you perceived -- narrower than is optimal. (I went through a phase of studying traditional book design when I started laying out text heavy web sites in the 90s, which had the negative side-effect of making me an effete snob about these things.)

elements.text: PG's essay has a width of 8-10, which is -- as you perceived -- narrower than is optimal. (I went through a phase of studying traditional book design when I started laying out text heavy web sites in the 90s, which had the negative side-effect of making me an effete snob about these things.)

text:
I really like the "accountability" framing of this post, and its analysis of various approaches in terms of trust and trust chains.

One aspect I find missing is that trust depends on everyone's personal context, and in particular on personal knowledge and competence, plus available resources. That's particularly true for proofs, which generate trust only for people who  understand them. For everyone else, including many domain experts who have other things to do with their life, it's back to trusting experts and other authorities.

Another aspect of trust that is missing is a legal framework (liability etc.). It's historically very weak for software, making it low-risk to do harm to others, knowingly or accidentally.

An aspect that you hint at but don't develop in detail is collective rather than individual trust, i.e. reputation.

For mature technologies, all sources of trust come together into what is more a web of trust than a trust chain. I use my Bosch power drill with little hesitation because (1) I trust the brand because of its reputation, (2) it's a widely used tool resulting from a long history of development, so its potential risks are well known, (3) consumer protection laws are pretty strong for such equipment.

text: Nothing substantive to add, but just want to say I really enjoyed this post! Covered a lot of ground and I liked the clear definitions of different dimensions to think about with trust. Bookmarked it to refer to next time I'm thinking about trust.
